text: Maybe it was all in the plan. But plans don't care. People do.
It was simple enough. A splash of water sustained a plant. A word of encouragement or "let me help you do that" would sustain a person.
The space that was for the people who were the heart of the business. The plant and the people both needed something.
In the back of my mind
column4: watering the plants part of my plan. Keep it alive. It  was a housewarming gift when we moved in to the offices.

text: It made me wonder if they noticed one another. Folks in a corner doing their job
column4: but without much engagement from the boss or a coworker.

text: The real issue is that I never told anyone that I was watering the plants. I guess no one noticed as we walked together to the kitchen.
People need one another just like that plant needed a little water.
That's when occurred to me. How many people in the office were also and malnourished during my absence?
Within a few hours
column4: it began to show signs of life. It was refreshed. Someone was tending to it‚Ä¶ even just a little

text: Now
column4: I took that plant to the kitchen
column5: trimmed a few dying leaves and soaked it in the kitchen sink.

text: But a two week vacation apparently meant to weeks without water for the plant.
It survived on those tiny splashes for years.
It was enough to sustain the plant.
I'd splash some water on it as I came and went from the kitchen to the next phone call or meeting.
Once
column4: there was a potted plant on a prominent path that led from the offices to the kitchen.
